results.title: David
results.creator_credit: Paul Dickson, James Carr, BFI and World Wide Pictures
results.brief_description: Illustrates the harsh reality of life in a coal mining town using documentary and fictional techniques. Made in Ammanford, Wales, the film recounts the life of Daffyd Rhys employed as a caretaker for the local school following a coal mine explosion. The story is related by one of the school’s former pupils and covers Daffyd’s early life in the coal mines, his courtship and marriage, his work as a poet, the death of his son, and his life at the school. Most of the roles are performed by the people of Ammanford resulting in a realistic portrayal of life in the Welsh coal mining community. The film was presented as Wales contribution to the Festival of Britain.

results.title: Daumier
results.creator_credit: Nico Crama and Mary Van Den Heyer
results.brief_description: Daumier was a ninteenth century eyewitness of England and Europe: the observer of great and small men. This film shows some of his lighographic cartoons and caricatures which relate to the period 1830-1873.

results.title: Date with history: Hiroshima
results.brief_description: Shows the preliminary events leading up to the bombing of Hiroshima in August, 1945 in which 72,000 people were killed. some of the people involved are interviewed, giving their reactions to the holocaust. The film contains actual footage of the events.

results.title: Date with Dizzy
results.creator_credit: John Hubley, Jim Di Gangi and Hubley Films
results.brief_description: A gentle satire on television commercials showing the production and use of effective advertising. Features Dizzy Gillespie and Quintet improvising a musical soundtrack for drawings made by John Hubley and his staff as they create animated-cartoon television commercials for a new product with unsuccessful results until the director screens three previous advertisements as examples of the desired effect. Concludes with a wild jam session led by Dizzy Gillespie. Several of the Hubley animation techniques are illustrated making this film useful for discussion on film technique.
results.creator_credit_for_label: John Hubley, Jim Di Gangi and Hubley Films

results.title: Data processing: an introduction
results.creator_credit: Dick Larson and Coronet Instructional Films
results.brief_description: Introduces the basic data processing functions of sorting data, collating material and calculating, beginning with manual methods and moving into punched card equipment. With electronic computer systems, we learn ways of increasing the speed and flexibility of processing, resulting in faster ways of handling greater quantities of data.

results.title: Dashes, hurdles and relays
results.creator_credit: Encyclopaedia Britannica Films and ERPI Classroom Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Athletics”.
A study of techniques for the 100 metres, 200 metres and 400 metres sprints; three types of good form for hurdling; and the technique of passing the baton in relay races.

results.title: Das Rheingold
results.creator_credit: Brian Large, Otto Schenk, Channel 4, Deutsche Grammophon, La Sept, Metropolitan Opera (New York, N.Y.) and Osterreichischer Rundfunk-Fernsehen
results.brief_description: In the first opera in Richard Wagner’s massive Ring Cycle, the Rhinegold is stolen by Alberich from the Rhine maidens and later fashioned into a ring of power, thus setting in train the saga which culminates in Die Gotterdammerung. The Metropolitan Opera Orchestra and Chorus is conducted by James Levine and the cast includes Christa Ludwig, Ekkehard Wlaschina, and James Morris. Sung in German, the video is accompanied by a synopsis. Wagner’s Ring Cycle consists of four parts, in this order: Das Rheingold; Die Walkuere; Siegfried and Goetterdaemmerung.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Brian Large, Otto Schenk, Channel 4, Deutsche Grammophon, La Sept, Metropolitan Opera (New York, N.Y.) and Osterreichischer Rundfunk-Fernsehen

results.title: Darwin and the theory of natural selection [b&w]
results.brief_description: Young Charles Darwin’s voyage on HMS Beagle resulted in discoveries that have had a profound effect on nearly every field of human knowledge. Through Darwin’s observations off the coasts and islands of South America and experiments made in England, we see how this scientist developed his Theory of Natural Selection. Many rare views of animal and plant life were photographed on the Galapagos Islands.

results.title: Darwin's finches: clues to the origin of species
results.creator_credit: Herbert Schick and Film Associates of California
results.brief_description: A simple introduction to the evidence in the Galapagos Islands fauna which Darwin first interpreted as due to natural selection of variants, particularly the adaptive radiation of the finches and iguanas into different ecological roles. Suitable for upper primary and secondary levels.
